ground_truth.question: Does German have a more complex grammar system than English?

questions: Is the grammar in German more complicated than in English?
Does English have a less complex system of grammar than German?
Does German have a harder grammar structure compared to English?
Is it true that German's grammar is more complex than that of English?
Compared to English, does German have a more intricate structure of grammar?
Would you say that German grammar is more complex than English?
When English and German are compared, does the latter have more complex grammar?
If you compare German and English, is German grammar more intricate?
Between German and English, which language has a more complicated grammar?
In terms of complexity, how does German grammar compare to English grammar?
answers: Yes, German grammar is more complex than English.
Quite true, German grammar is more complex.
Correct, German uses a more complex system of grammar than English.
Right, German grammar is indeed more complicated.
Indeed, the grammar of German is more complex.
Exactly, German grammar is more complex than English grammar.
context: German (German: Deutsch) is a West Germanic language. It is spoken in Germany, Austria, Switzerland, Liechtenstein and Luxembourg; natively by around 100 million people. It is the most widely spoken mother tongue in the first language. There are some people who speak German in Belgium, The Netherlands, France and Northern Italy. There are people who speak German in many countries, including the United States and Canada, where many people emigrated from Germany. It is also spoken in Eastern Europe, Bulgaria, Romania, and Russia. German is a part of the West Germanic language family and is much like English and Dutch. Much of the vocabulary in German is related to English, but the grammar is more complicated. German has a system of cases, and when helping verbs are used, the main part of the verb must be moved to the end of the sentence. For example, "Someone has stolen my car" is Jemand hat mein Auto gestohlen ("Someone has my car stolen"), and "Someone called me last night" is Jemand hat mich letzte Nacht angerufen ("Someone has me last night called"). In writing, every noun must start with a capital letter. German is the only language that still has that rule, but Danish and English did so a long time ago. Standard German is an official language in Switzerland, but the Swiss dialect of German is difficult to understand for native speakers from Germany and even for Swiss who are not native to speaking German. One reason that the dialects are still so different today is that even if Switzerland adopted Standard German, mostly as a written standard, German Swiss in World War II wanted to separate themselves from the Nazis by choosing to speak dialect over the Standard German. Swiss German also has some differences in spelling, for example, the letter ß, which is used only in German, is replaced by ss. thumb == Dialects == * Alsatian * Bavarian dialect * Franconian Dialect * Kölsch * Low Saxon * Swiss dialect * Mannheimerisch dialect * Palatinate German * Russian (Siberian) dialect == German numbers == German numbers are similar to their English counterparts. Like most languages, the German number system is based mainly on the first 10 numbers. They will pop up over and over throughout all the higher numbers. English German 1 Eins 2 Zwei 3 Drei 4 Vier 5 Fünf 6 Sechs 7 Sieben 8 Acht 9 Neun 10 Zehn ==References== Notes == Other websites == *Online German Language Course An online German language course that includes lessons covering pronunciation, vocabulary, and grammar. *German phrasebook at Wikivoyage *Learn to Speak German Student Resource *Free German Language Course *German Thesaurus
